questions.text: A tuberculosis patient receiving anti-tubercular treatment complains of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs. He is not diabetic and drinks alcohol on occasion. Which of the following vitamins should be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients receiving isoniazid as part of anti-tubercular therapy should be supplemented with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) to prevent or treat peripheral neuropathy, a common side effect of this medication.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the electrolyte composition of 'ReSoMal' oral rehydration salts solution used for malnourished children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition) is specifically formulated for rehydrating children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). The sodium content in ReSoMal is 45 mmol/L, not 65 mmol/L as stated in option C. This reduced sodium concentration is intentional because malnourished children have excess body sodium despite presenting with low serum sodium levels. The standard WHO ORS contains 90 mmol/L sodium, which is too high for malnourished children.
  • • The correct composition of ReSoMal includes:
  • • Sodium: 45 mmol/L Potassium: 40 mmol/L Chloride: 70 mmol/L Glucose: 125 mmol/L Magnesium: 3 mmol/L Zinc: 0.3 mmol/L Copper: 0.045 mmol/L
  • • Sodium: 45 mmol/L
  • • Potassium: 40 mmol/L
  • • Chloride: 70 mmol/L
  • • Glucose: 125 mmol/L
  • • Magnesium: 3 mmol/L
  • • Zinc: 0.3 mmol/L
  • • Copper: 0.045 mmol/L
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Copper 0.045 mmol/L - Correct . ReSoMal contains copper at a concentration of 0.045 mmol/L, which helps address micronutrient deficiencies common in malnourished children.
  • • Option A. Copper 0.045 mmol/L - Correct
  • • Option B. Potassium 40 mmol/L - Correct . ReSoMal has increased potassium (40 mmol/L) compared to standard ORS (20 mmol/L) to address potassium depletion in malnourished children.
  • • Option B. Potassium 40 mmol/L - Correct
  • • Option D. Magnesium 3 mmol/L - Correct . ReSoMal contains magnesium at 3 mmol/L to help correct magnesium deficiency commonly seen in severe malnutrition.
  • • Option D. Magnesium 3 mmol/L - Correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ReSoMal has a lower sodium concentration (45 mmol/L) and higher potassium concentration (40 mmol/L) than standard ORS to address the specific electrolyte abnormalities in severe acute malnutrition. This specialized formulation helps prevent complications like heart failure during rehydration therapy in malnourished children.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Selegiline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that increases dopamine availability in the brain and is used to manage the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as rigidity and tremors.

questions.text: Lignocaine is used in a loading dose for the treatment of arrhythmias. The loading dose of this drug depends upon which of the following factors? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Volume of distribution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The volume of distribution is the key factor that determines the loading dose of a drug, especially in intravenous administration where bioavailability is 100%
  • ➤ volume of distribution

questions.text: Which medication is considered the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Benign Rolandic Epilepsy, also known as Benign Childhood Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), is one of the most common childhood epilepsy syndromes. Sodium valproate is considered the drug of choice for this condition due to its broad spectrum antiepileptic properties and effectiveness in controlling both partial and generalized seizures. It works by increasing brain levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter.
  • • Benign Rolandic Epilepsy typically presents with focal seizures involving the face, particularly during sleep, and has a characteristic EEG pattern with centrotemporal spikes. The condition is self-limiting and generally resolves by adolescence, but antiepileptic therapy may be needed during the active phase.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gabapentin - Incorrect . While gabapentin is used as an anticonvulsant, it is not the first-line therapy for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy. It is more commonly used for neuropathic pain and as adjunctive therapy for partial seizures.
  • • Option A. Gabapentin - Incorrect
  • • Option C. Barbiturates - Incorrect . Barbiturates are older generation antiepileptic drugs with significant side effects including sedation and cognitive impairment. They are rarely used as first-line therapy for childhood epilepsies today.
  • • Option C. Barbiturates - Incorrect
  • • Option D. Phenytoin - Incorrect . Phenytoin is primarily effective against generalized tonic-clonic and partial seizures but is not the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its side effect profile and pharmacokinetic variability in children.
  • • Option D. Phenytoin - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sodium valproate is the preferred first-line treatment for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its efficacy and relatively favorable side effect profile compared to other antiepileptic medications in children.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is INCORRECT? (NEET PG 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children.

options.label: C
options.text: Initial management typically involves prednisolone at 60 mg/day.

options.label: D
options.text: Remission is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.

questions.correct_answer: D. Remission is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Remission is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Remission in nephrotic syndrome is defined by the absence of proteinuria (nil/trace) for 3 consecutive days or proteinuria <4 mg/m²/hr, while a urine protein ratio >2 indicates ongoing heavy proteinuria, not remission.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is diagnosed with osteosarcoma and is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy as part of his treatment. Methotrexate is included in his chemotherapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of his osteosarcoma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate's primary mechanism of action in treating osteosarcoma is as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency of the nutrient as given in the image of a child: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zinc deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Characteristic skin manifestations of acrodermatitis enteropathica as a sign of zinc deficiency, which includes eczematous lesions accompanied by systemic symptoms like diarrhea and brittle nails.
  • ➤ acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK9 inhibitor? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that works by blocking the PCSK9 enzyme, leading to increased LDL receptor availability on liver cells and reduced LDL cholesterol levels in the blood.

questions.text: A person was taking an antihypertensive drug and continued taking it despite developing constipation, dry mouth, and dizziness. He was taking it regularly but forgot to take it during a trip abroad and has now developed a hypertensive emergency. Which antihypertensive was he likely taking? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clonidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clonidine is an antihypertensive medication that can cause dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, and sudden discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, making it crucial for patients to maintain consistent dosing.

questions.text: Which phenomenon describes vertigo induced by loud sounds? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tullio Phenomenon

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tullio phenomenon refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus in response to loud sounds. This occurs due to a pathological connection between the sound-conducting system and the vestibular apparatus. Loud sounds cause abnormal stimulation of the vestibular system, resulting in vestibular symptoms. This phenomenon is seen in conditions like superior semicircular canal dehiscence, perilymphatic fistula, and advanced otosyphilis where there is an abnormal communication between the inner ear fluid compartments.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hennebert's Sign : This refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus on applying pressure to the external auditory canal (positive fistula test) in the absence of a demonstrable fistula (false positive). It is typically seen in congenital syphilis due to the presence of fibrous adhesions between the stapes footplate and the membranous labyrinth. Unlike Tullio phenomenon which is triggered by sound, Hennebert's sign is elicited by pressure changes.
  • • Option B. Hennebert's Sign
  • • Option C. Roll-over Phenomenon : This is seen in retrocochlear hearing loss (e.g., acoustic neuroma). It refers to a decrease in speech discrimination scores as the intensity of sound is increased beyond a certain level. Unlike Tullio phenomenon, it does not involve vertigo and is related to hearing discrimination rather than vestibular function.
  • • Option C. Roll-over Phenomenon
  • • Option D. Recruitment Phenomenon : This is the abnormal growth of loudness perception seen in cochlear hearing loss. Patients with cochlear lesions have difficulty hearing soft sounds, but as intensity increases, they perceive loudness as rapidly growing to normal or even uncomfortable levels. This phenomenon affects hearing rather than balance and does not cause vertigo.
  • • Option D. Recruitment Phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tullio phenomenon specifically describes the vestibular symptoms (vertigo and nystagmus) induced by loud sounds due to pathological communication between the sound-conducting and vestibular systems of the inner ear.

questions.text: Identify A and B in the image given: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-Anopheles, B-Culex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a study based in Delhi from 2012-2022, doctors followed up 100 people who did exercise on a daily basis for a year. Later, they checked who all had developed coronary heart disease among them. This is a type of: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prospective study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A study that starts with exposure, follows subjects over time, and measures outcomes later is a prospective/cohort study.

questions.text: Which virus is the most common cause of croup in children? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Parainfluenza virus (especially types 1 and 2) is the most common cause of croup in children, accounting for approximately 75% of all cases. Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is characterized by barky cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor resulting from inflammation and narrowing of the subglottic area. Parainfluenza virus causes inflammation and edema of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, with the narrowest portion of the pediatric airway (subglottic region) being particularly affected.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) - Incorrect. RSV is the leading cause of bronchiolitis in children under 2 years of age, but it is not the primary causative agent of croup. RSV affects the lower respiratory tract, causing inflammation of the small airways (bronchioles).
  • • Option A. Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
  • • Option B. Influenza - Incorrect. While influenza can cause croup-like symptoms, it is not the most common viral cause. Influenza typically causes more systemic symptoms like high fever, myalgia, and fatigue in addition to respiratory symptoms.
  • • Option B. Influenza
  • • Option D. Streptococcus Pneumoniae - Incorrect. This is a bacterium, not a virus. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a major cause of bacterial pneumonia, otitis media, and sinusitis, but not typically associated with croup, which is predominantly viral in etiology.
  • • Option D. Streptococcus Pneumoniae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of viral croup in children, typically presenting with the classic triad of barky cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness, with symptoms often worsening at night.

questions.text: What is the f-IPV dose schedule under the National Immunization Schedule of India? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: B
options.text: At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 6 weeks, 14 weeks, 9 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fractional IPV (f-IPV) schedule in India's National Immunization Schedule consists of three doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 months.
  • ➤ 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 months.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Kwashiorkor is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.correct_answer: D. All Skin and Bone Appearance
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition primarily due to protein deficiency while maintaining relatively adequate caloric intake. The "all skin and bone appearance" is characteristic of marasmus, not kwashiorkor. Children with kwashiorkor typically have edema that masks the muscle wasting, giving them a falsely "plump" appearance. They have a distended abdomen, edema (especially of the feet and legs), and fatty liver due to decreased lipoprotein production and transport.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Moaning Cry - This is a true feature of kwashiorkor. Children with kwashiorkor often have a characteristic plaintive, moaning cry due to general irritability and weakness.
  • • Option A. Moaning Cry
  • • Option B. Red-Haired Boy - This is a true feature. Kwashiorkor causes depigmentation of hair, leading to reddish or yellowish discoloration (flag sign), particularly noticeable in children with naturally dark hair.
  • • Option B. Red-Haired Boy
  • • Option C. Mosaic Dermatitis - This is a true feature of kwashiorkor. Also called "flaky paint dermatosis," the skin develops patches that crack and peel, particularly in areas exposed to repeated friction or pressure.
  • • Option C. Mosaic Dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, red/blonde hair discoloration, irritability, and mosaic dermatosis, while the "all skin and bone" appearance is typical of marasmus due to calorie deficiency with relative sparing of protein.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Astemizole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Astemizole is a drug that, when taken with erythromycin, can lead to QT prolongation and the serious arrhythmia known as Torsades de pointes. This significant adverse effect led to the withdrawal of Astemizole from the market in many countries.

questions.text: A patient with renal insufficiency had very low urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure of 160/90. Which antihypertensive medication can be used? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amlodipine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amlodipine is the preferred antihypertensive medication for patients with renal insufficiency, as it effectively lowers blood pressure without negatively impacting renal function.

questions.text: Which neonatal condition is the gastric aspirate shake test used to evaluate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The gastric aspirate shake test is a simple bedside test used to assess pulmonary surfactant in newborns. It evaluates the presence of surfactant in gastric aspirate, which correlates with surfactant levels in the lungs. This test is specifically used to evaluate for Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), also known as Hyaline Membrane Disease, which is caused by surfactant deficiency in premature infants.
  • • In this test, gastric fluid is aspirated from the newborn and mixed with ethanol and saline. The mixture is then shaken and observed for stable foam formation. The presence of stable foam indicates adequate surfactant (negative test), while absence of foam indicates surfactant deficiency (positive test), suggesting RDS.
  • • The test is particularly valuable in resource-limited settings where more sophisticated tests like amniotic fluid lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio or lamellar body counts may not be available.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tracheoesophageal fistula - Incorrect. Diagnosis of TEF usually involves passing a radiopaque nasogastric tube and obtaining radiographs to demonstrate coiling of the tube in the proximal esophageal pouch. The shake test has no role in diagnosing TEF.
  • • Option B. Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • • Option C. Meconium aspiration syndrome - Incorrect. MAS is diagnosed based on history of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, clinical signs of respiratory distress, and characteristic radiographic findings. The shake test is not used in MAS evaluation.
  • • Option C. Meconium aspiration syndrome
  • • Option D. Transient tachypnea of the newborn - Incorrect. TTN is diagnosed based on clinical presentation and radiographic findings showing fluid in the interlobar fissures and perihilar streaking. The shake test doesn't help in TTN diagnosis as surfactant levels are normal in TTN.
  • • Option D. Transient tachypnea of the newborn

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gastric aspirate shake test is a simple bedside test to evaluate surfactant deficiency in neonates, helping to diagnose Respiratory Distress Syndrome, particularly in settings where sophisticated laboratory tests are unavailable.

questions.text: A patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia developed flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes. Which drug is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nicotinamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nicotinamide (niacin) is associated with flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes, making it the likely cause of these symptoms in a patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia

questions.text: Stoss therapy is utilized for the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Stoss therapy refers to the administration of a large single dose or a few divided doses of vitamin D for the rapid correction of vitamin D deficiency. This therapy is specifically designed for treating nutritional vitamin D deficiency rickets. It typically involves giving a high dose of vitamin D (typically 300,000-600,000 IU) as either a single dose or divided over a few days.
  • • The advantages of Stoss therapy include improved compliance (as it requires fewer doses) and rapid correction of deficiency. After the initial high-dose therapy, maintenance doses of vitamin D are continued to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly useful in situations where compliance with daily supplementation might be challenging.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Scurvy - Incorrect. Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency and is treated with vitamin C supplementation (100-200 mg/day for 3 months), not high-dose vitamin D therapy.
  • • Option A. Scurvy
  • • Option B. Keratomalacia - Incorrect. Keratomalacia is a condition resulting from severe vitamin A deficiency affecting the cornea. It requires vitamin A supplementation, not vitamin D. Treatment usually involves 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally on day 1, repeated on day 2 and after 2 weeks.
  • • Option B. Keratomalacia -
  • • Option D. Hypophosphatemic rickets - Incorrect. Hypophosphatemic rickets (vitamin D-resistant rickets) is typically hereditary and caused by phosphate wasting, not vitamin D deficiency. It is treated with phosphate supplements and calcitriol, not high-dose vitamin D therapy.
  • • Option D. Hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stoss therapy is specifically used for treating vitamin D deficiency rickets with large doses (300,000-600,000 IU) given over a short period, providing rapid correction and improved compliance compared to daily supplementation regimens.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic is correctly matched with its site of action ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal tubule

questions.text: Which structure develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ductus arteriosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ductus arteriosus, a critical structure in fetal circulation, develops from the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes infection involving the geniculate ganglion? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes zoster infection (varicella-zoster virus) involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It presents as a triad of facial nerve palsy, vesicular eruptions on the pinna and external auditory canal, and vestibulocochlear symptoms. The infection represents a reactivation of the herpes zoster virus that had remained dormant in the geniculate ganglion after previous chickenpox infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome : This is a rare manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, and facial nerve palsy. It is not related to herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion. The facial palsy in this condition is due to granulomatous infiltration of the facial nerve.
  • • Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome
  • • Option C. Bell's Palsy : While this is also a facial nerve paralysis, Bell's palsy is idiopathic in nature. Although some theories suggest that herpes simplex virus may be involved in some cases of Bell's palsy, it does not specifically involve vesicular eruptions or definitive evidence of geniculate ganglion involvement as seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.
  • • Option C. Bell's Palsy
  • • Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome : This syndrome (also called Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome) is characterized by recurrent or persistent facial swelling, recurrent facial paralysis, and a fissured tongue (lingua plicata). It is not caused by herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion but is thought to be related to granulomatous disease.
  • • Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is specifically characterized by facial nerve palsy due to herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion, presenting with the distinctive triad of facial paralysis, ear/mouth vesicles, and auditory/vestibular symptoms.

questions.text: Hecht's Pneumonia is typically associated with which of the following infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hecht's pneumonia refers to the giant cell pneumonia that occurs as a complication of measles infection. It is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) in the lung tissue, which are pathognomonic for measles. This form of pneumonia represents a serious complication of measles and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Measles virus directly infects the respiratory epithelium, leading to necrosis and the formation of these characteristic giant cells in the lungs.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Malaria - Incorrect. Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by Plasmodium species transmitted by mosquitoes. While it can cause pulmonary complications (particularly P. falciparum), it does not cause Hecht's pneumonia or the formation of multinucleated giant cells in the lungs.
  • • Option B. Malaria
  • • Option C. RSV - Incorrect. Respiratory Syncytial Virus causes bronchiolitis and pneumonia, especially in young children, but is not associated with Hecht's pneumonia or giant cell formation. RSV typically causes inflammation of the bronchioles with mucus plugging and epithelial cell necrosis.
  • • Option C. RSV
  • • Option D. Pneumococcus - Incorrect. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common bacterial cause of community-acquired pneumonia in all age groups, but causes a lobar pneumonia pattern with neutrophilic infiltration, not giant cell pneumonia.
  • • Option D. Pneumococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hecht's pneumonia (giant cell pneumonia) is a specific and severe complication of measles infection, characterized by the pathognomonic Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in lung tissue, and represents one of the serious complications that can occur with measles.

questions.text: What is the length of the external auditory canal in an adult? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 24 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The external auditory canal in an adult measures about 24 mm along its posterior wall. This is the standard anatomical length of the external auditory canal. The canal is not straight but has a slight S-shape, with the outer part directed upwards, backwards, and medially, while the inner part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 16 mm : This is incorrect for the total length of the external auditory canal. However, 16 mm specifically represents the length of the bony part of the external auditory canal, which forms the inner two-thirds of the total canal.
  • • Option A. 16 mm
  • • Option B. 20 mm : This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is longer than 20 mm in adults.
  • • Option B. 20 mm
  • • Option D. 28 mm : This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is shorter than 28 mm in adults.
  • • Option D. 28 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The external auditory canal in adults measures approximately 24 mm along its posterior wall and consists of a cartilaginous part (outer one-third, approximately 8 mm) and a bony part (inner two-thirds, approximately 16 mm).

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acetaminophen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetaminophen is the preferred postoperative analgesic for patients with chronic kidney disease, as it does not significantly affect renal function and is safer than NSAIDs in this population.

questions.text: In polyarticular onset juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), the condition involves more than how many joints? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is defined by the involvement of 5 or more joints during the first 6 months of disease. This subtype of JIA affects approximately 25-40% of children with juvenile arthritis and can be further classified as rheumatoid factor positive or negative.
  • • The classification of JIA is based on the number of joints involved in the initial 6 months:
  • • Oligoarticular JIA: affects 4 or fewer joints Polyarticular JIA: affects 5 or more joints Systemic JIA: characterized by arthritis with systemic features including fever and rash
  • • Oligoarticular JIA: affects 4 or fewer joints
  • • Polyarticular JIA: affects 5 or more joints
  • • Systemic JIA: characterized by arthritis with systemic features including fever and rash
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 3 - Incorrect . Involvement of 3 joints would be classified as oligoarticular JIA, which is defined as arthritis affecting 4 or fewer joints.
  • • Option A. 3 - Incorrect
  • • Option B. 4 - Incorrect . Involvement of 4 joints would still be classified as oligoarticular JIA.
  • • Option B. 4 - Incorrect
  • • Option D. 6 - Incorrect . While 6 joints would qualify as polyarticular JIA, the minimum threshold is 5 joints, not 6.
  • • Option D. 6 - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polyarticular JIA is defined by involvement of ≥5 joints during the first 6 months, while oligoarticular JIA involves ≤4 joints. This distinction is critical for proper classification, treatment approach, and prognostication.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atropine toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. She is prescribed metronidazole as part of her treatment plan. Which of the following should she avoid consuming while on this medication? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drugs that can cause disulfiram like reaction include:
  • ➤ C yclic: C efoperazone, C hlorpropamide
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ G: G rieseofulvin
  • ➤ G: G
  • ➤ M: M etronidazole
  • ➤ M: M
  • ➤ P: P rocarbazine
  • ➤ P: P

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for assessing non-organic hearing loss? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fowler Test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fowler Test (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance Test) is not used for diagnosing non-organic hearing loss. It is specifically designed to detect and measure recruitment in unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. In this test, tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented alternately to both ears, and the patient is asked to compare loudness. The test helps identify cochlear pathology by demonstrating recruitment phenomenon, where sounds that are barely audible reach uncomfortable loudness with small increases in intensity.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Stenger's Test : This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss, particularly unilateral feigned hearing loss. It employs the principle that when tones of different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, only the louder tone is perceived. If a patient with claimed unilateral deafness denies hearing a tone presented to both ears (with the "deaf" ear receiving a stronger stimulus), malingering is confirmed.
  • • Option A. Stenger's Test
  • • Option C. Lombard's Test : This is correctly used to detect non-organic hearing loss. It relies on the principle that people unconsciously raise their voice when they cannot hear themselves speak. In this test, the patient is asked to read aloud while noise is introduced to their ears. A genuine hearing-impaired person will raise their voice, while a malingerer maintaining normal voice level reveals non-organic hearing loss.
  • • Option C. Lombard's Test
  • • Option D. Erhardt's Test : This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss. It employs tuning forks that appear identical but vibrate at different frequencies. The patient is shown which fork corresponds to which tone but cannot actually see which fork is being used in testing. Inconsistent responses reveal the non-organic nature of the hearing loss.
  • • Option D. Erhardt's Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Fowler Test (ABLB) is designed specifically to detect recruitment in sensorineural hearing loss, particularly of cochlear origin, and is not part of the standard test battery for identifying non-organic hearing loss or malingering.

questions.text: A patient has come to the clinic. Identify the movement being examined in the given image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Abduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Trendelenburg test assesses the function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. A positive Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of these muscles, often due to damage to the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal structure connecting the spleen to the kidney and contains the splenic artery. This ligament is essential for surgeons to identify, especially during procedures involving the spleen or splenic artery.

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is contraindicated in iron poisoning? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) BAL (British Anti-Lewisite)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) is contraindicated in Cadmium and Iron poisoning.
  • ➤ Desferrioxamine is the appropriate chelating agent to use in cases of iron poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the patch used in the given figure is correct? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: It is an Equal Mixture of Local Anesthetics

options.label: B
options.text: It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine in a ratio of 50 percent each

options.label: C
options.text: Excessive use can result in methemoglobinemia

options.label: D
options.text: 5 ml of 5 percent mixture contains 50 mg lignocaine

questions.correct_answer: C. Excessive use can result in methemoglobinemia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Excessive use can result in methemoglobinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prilocaine, one of the components of the EMLA patch, can cause methemoglobinemia, especially when used in excessive amounts or in vulnerable populations like infants.

questions.text: During endoscopy, the endoscope has reached 25 cm from the incisor teeth. The endoscope has reached till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Arch of aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 25 cm from the incisor teeth during an endoscopy, the endoscope has reached the level of the arch of aorta. This is a crucial anatomical landmark and is typically located at the T4 vertebra level

questions.text: Round pneumonia is most commonly associated with which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Round pneumonia is a distinct radiological pattern of pneumonia that appears as a round or oval opacity on chest imaging, mimicking a mass lesion. It is most commonly associated with Streptococcal pneumonia (Streptococcus pneumoniae infection). This presentation is particularly common in children under 8 years of age due to the lack of development of complete interlobular septae and pores of Kohn, which allows infection to spread more uniformly in a centrifugal pattern rather than respecting anatomical boundaries. Round pneumonia typically resolves completely with appropriate antibiotic therapy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Kerosene oil aspiration - Incorrect. Kerosene aspiration typically causes chemical pneumonitis with bilateral infiltrates, often with a predominantly basal distribution. It does not present as round pneumonia but rather as diffuse or patchy infiltrates.
  • • Option B. Kerosene oil aspiration
  • • Option C. Lung cancer - Incorrect. While lung cancer can present as a round mass on imaging, this is not classified as round pneumonia. Round pneumonia is an infectious process that resolves with antibiotics, unlike malignant lesions.
  • • Option C. Lung cancer
  • • Option D. Mendelson syndrome - Incorrect. This refers to chemical pneumonitis caused by aspiration of acidic gastric contents. It typically presents with bilateral infiltrates in dependent lung zones, not as a solitary round opacity.
  • • Option D. Mendelson syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Round pneumonia is a distinct radiological presentation most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae infection in children, appearing as a well-defined round opacity that may mimic a tumor but resolves completely with appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is not responding well to conventional treatment. Her rheumatologist is considering adding tocilizumab to her treatment regimen. Which of the following interleukins (IL) is primarily targeted by tocilizumab? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IL-6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tocilizumab targets the IL-6 receptor, making it effective for managing rheumatoid arthritis and certain other inflammatory conditions by inhibiting the IL-6 signaling pathway.

questions.text: National Deworming Day is observed on:(FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 10 February and 10 August

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ National Deworming Day is observed on 10th February with a repeat round after 6 months on 10th August , using albendazole for deworming .
  • ➤ 10th February
  • ➤ after 6 months on 10th August
  • ➤ albendazole for deworming

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Which congenital heart disease is most commonly associated with Down's Syndrome? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD), also known as endocardial cushion defect or atrioventricular canal defect, is the most commonly associated congenital heart defect in Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). About 40-60% of children with Down syndrome have congenital heart disease, and AVSD is the most specific cardiac anomaly, accounting for approximately 30-40% of these cardiac defects. AVSD occurs due to failure of proper development of the endocardial cushions, which are essential for the formation of the lower portion of the atrial septum, the upper portion of the ventricular septum, and the mitral and tricuspid valves.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) - Incorrect. While PDA can occur in Down syndrome, it is not the most common or specific cardiac defect associated with the condition. PDA represents failure of the fetal connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery to close after birth.
  • • Option A. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
  • • Option B. Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) - Incorrect. Ostium secundum ASD is common in Down syndrome but not as specific or prevalent as AVSD. The ostium primum type of ASD is actually part of the AVSD spectrum.
  • • Option B. Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)
  • • Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) - Incorrect. TOF occurs in approximately 6-8% of Down syndrome patients with cardiac defects but is not the most common cardiac anomaly in this population. TOF is more commonly associated with 22q11 deletion syndrome.
  • • Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) is the most common and specific congenital heart defect in Down syndrome, affecting approximately 30-40% of patients with cardiac anomalies due to abnormal development of the endocardial cushions.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enhance fibrin degradation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) enhances fibrin degradation by converting plasminogen to plasmin, leading to the dissolution of blood clots.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Varicella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Live attenuated vaccines (like Varicella, MMR, Yellow fever) are contraindicated during pregnancy, while killed/inactivated vaccines and toxoids are safe and often recommended during pregnancy.
  • ➤ CONTRAINDICATIONS, AEFI
  • ➤ Contraindications

questions.text: During a surgical procedure in the ear, the surgeon injured a nerve which led to lagophthalmos after the surgery. Which nerve was likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve (Cranial Nerve 7) controls the muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi muscle, and injury to this nerve can result in lagophthalmos.

questions.text: A term infant has a preductal oxygen saturation of 85%, 5 minutes after birth. Which of the following is true? (NEET PG 2016)

options.label: C
options.text: This infant is achieving desired target oxygen saturation.

options.label: D
options.text: Supplemental oxygen should be given at 100% concentration.

questions.correct_answer: C. This infant is achieving desired target oxygen saturation.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Normal oxygen saturation in newborns follows a predictable pattern after birth as the transition from fetal to neonatal circulation occurs. According to neonatal resuscitation guidelines, the preductal oxygen saturation (measured at right hand) at 5 minutes of life should be between 80-85%. The target ranges progress from 60-65% at 1 minute, 65-70% at 2 minutes, 70-75% at 3 minutes, 75-80% at 4 minutes, 80-85% at 5 minutes, and 85-95% at 10 minutes. Therefore, a preductal oxygen saturation of 85% at 5 minutes is within the normal range for a newborn and does not require intervention.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Oxygen supplementation is necessary - Incorrect. Supplemental oxygen is not needed when SpO2 is within normal range for age in minutes. Unnecessary oxygen can cause hyperoxemia and oxidative stress.
  • • Option A. Oxygen supplementation is necessary
  • • Option B. Cyanotic heart disease is suspected - Incorrect. This oxygen level is normal for a 5-minute-old infant, not suggestive of congenital heart disease. PaO2 <100mmHg despite 100% oxygen for 10-15 minutes - hyperoxia test fail suggesting cyanotic heart disease is likely.
  • • Option B. Cyanotic heart disease is suspected
  • • Option D. Supplemental oxygen should be given at 100% concentration - Incorrect. Not only is supplemental oxygen unnecessary at this saturation, but 100% oxygen is no longer recommended in neonatal resuscitation except in specific circumstances.
  • • Option D. Supplemental oxygen should be given at 100% concentration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Normal oxygen saturation in newborns rises gradually after birth, with 80-85% being the normal target range at 5 minutes of life. Understanding these normal transitional physiology values prevents unnecessary oxygen administration.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Mucormycosis:
  • ➤ Treatment of Mucormycosis:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate. The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy. Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary. Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate.
  • ➤ The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy.
  • ➤ Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary.
  • ➤ Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

questions.text: Otosclerosis most commonly begins at which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fissula Ante-fenestram

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Otosclerosis most commonly begins at the fissula ante fenestram. This is a small depression located in front of the oval window in the otic capsule. This is the initial site where the abnormal bone remodeling process begins, which eventually extends to involve the stapes footplate causing its fixation and conductive hearing loss. The fissula ante fenestrum is considered the classic starting point for otosclerotic lesions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Fossula Post-fenestram : While otosclerotic foci can develop in various locations within the otic capsule, the fossula post-fenestram (behind the oval window) is not the most common initial site. Otosclerosis predominantly begins at the area anterior to the oval window (fissula ante fenestram).
  • • Option B. Fossula Post-fenestram
  • • Option C. Footplate of Stapes : Although the stapes footplate is eventually involved in otosclerosis, leading to the characteristic stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss, it is not typically the primary site where the disease process begins. The disease usually starts in the fissula ante fenestram and then extends to involve the footplate.
  • • Option C. Footplate of Stapes
  • • Option D. Oval Window : The oval window itself is not the initial site of otosclerotic change. The oval window is the opening between the middle and inner ear into which the stapes footplate fits. Otosclerosis begins in the bone adjacent to this structure (in the fissula ante fenestram) and then extends to involve the stapes footplate and oval window area.
  • • Option D. Oval Window

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis characteristically begins in the fissula ante fenestram (anterior to the oval window) before extending to involve the stapes footplate, causing the fixation that leads to conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal capsule is a key white matter structure that lies between the thalamus and the lentiform nucleus, transmitting important motor and sensory pathways to the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: What is the most prevalent defect observed in Congenital Rubella Syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) is characterized by a triad of defects including sensorineural hearing loss, ocular abnormalities (such as cataracts), and congenital heart defects. Among these manifestations, sensorineural deafness is the most common and prevalent defect, affecting approximately 80% of infants with CRS. The hearing impairment is typically bilateral and can range from mild to profound.
  • • The classic triad of CRS includes:
  • • Sensorineural deafness (most common) Eye abnormalities (cataracts, microphthalmia, glaucoma) Cardiac defects (most commonly PDA)
  • • Sensorineural deafness (most common)
  • • Eye abnormalities (cataracts, microphthalmia, glaucoma)
  • • Cardiac defects (most commonly PDA)
  • • The risk of defects is highest when maternal infection occurs during the first trimester, particularly before 11 weeks of gestation, when the risk of defects is approximately 90%.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cataract - Incorrect . While cataracts are a characteristic feature of CRS, they are less common than hearing impairment, occurring in approximately 30-40% of affected infants.
  • • Option B. Cataract - Incorrect
  • • Option C. Heart defect - Incorrect . Cardiac defects (particularly PDA, followed by peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis) occur in about 50-60% of CRS cases, making them less prevalent than deafness.
  • • Option C. Heart defect - Incorrect
  • • Option D. Microcephaly - Incorrect . Microcephaly is observed in CRS but at a lower frequency compared to hearing impairment. It is part of the neurological manifestations that may include developmental delay and intellectual disability.
  • • Option D. Microcephaly - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sensorineural deafness is the most common manifestation of Congenital Rubella Syndrome, which is why hearing assessment is critical for all infants with suspected in-utero rubella exposure, even in the absence of other clinical features.

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection for the treatment of wrinkles. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft

options.label: C
options.text: Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors

questions.correct_answer: A. Inhibits the release of acetylcholine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by cleaving SNARE proteins, thereby preventing neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction and leading to muscle relaxation.
